ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: MetaTrial Visit ID
Notes: System variable: unique code for each type of visit -use to merge files

ElementDescription: Visit name
Notes: e.g., Baseline, 6-Month Follow Up, Year 2, Daily

ElementDescription: Truncated Visit Number
Notes: "Created variable: provides a numeric visit number for all visits, including unscheduled and end of phase"

ElementDescription: Current Phase. Phase patient was in at the time of the assessment Phase 4 refers to the follow-up phase.
ValueRange: Pre-Rand; Phase 1/1A; Phase 2; Phase 3; Phase 4; Phase 1B; Open-Choice Phase; Screening; Phase 1

ElementDescription: Number of days from study baseline to date of visit
"Have you at any time had mental (nerve, worry) problems that were different from most other people's?"
Notes: "0=The patient states that no problems existed and that treatment was completely unnecessary, or gives nonsensical answers; 1=The patient acknowledges only anxiety, sleep disturbances, arguing, or being upset, and elieves that treatment may not have been necessary; or states that he/she went along with treatment because important others felt he/she was ill and should be treated; 2=The patient acknowledges the presence of delusional beliefs, hallucinatory experiences or disorganized thoughts, and views these as serious problems which required substantial intervention"

ElementDescription: Have you at any time needed treatment (hospitalization or outpatient care) for mental problems?
Notes: "0=The patient states that no problems existed and that treatment was completely unnecessary, or gives nonsensical answers; 1=The patient acknowledges only anxiety, sleep disturbances, arguing, or being upset, and elieves that treatment may not have been necessary; or states that he/she went along with treatment because important others felt he/she was ill and should be treated; 2=The patient acknowledges the presence of delusional beliefs, hallucinatory experiences or disorganized thoughts, and views these as serious problems which required substantial intervention"

ElementDescription: "Do you now have mental (nerve, worry) problems?"
Notes: "0=The patient believes there never were any problems, there are no problems now, and there is certainly no need for treatment; 1= The patient states that all problems which had been present are now completely gone, and that there is no more need for concern. He or she is unclear as to why treatment is continuing but willing to go along if told to do so by his/her family or physician; 2=The patient acknowledges that some psychopathology is still present, or if symptoms have cleared, that the illness has been controlled but not completely cured. He or she views recovery as the happy result of successful treatment."

ElementDescription: Do you now need treatment (hospitalization or outpatient care) for mental problems?
Notes: "0 = The patient believes there never were any problems, there are no problems now, and there is certainly no need for treatment; 1= The patient states that all problems which had been present are now completely gone, and that there is no more need for concern. He or she is unclear as to why treatment is continuing but willing to go along if told to do so by his/her family or physician; 2=The patient acknowledges that some psychopathology is still present, or if symptoms have cleared, that the illness has been controlled but not completely cured. He or she views recovery as the happy result of successful treatment."

ElementDescription: "Is it possible that in the future you may have mental (nerve, worry) problems?"
Notes: "0=The patient assures us that there will be no mental problems in his/her future, and that maintenance treatment is completely unnecessary; 1=The patient is unsure about the possibility of relapse or the need for maintenance treatment, but will participate if told to do so by his/her family or physician; 2=The patient is aware that schizophrenia is a chronic illness, like diabetes or hypertension, and that maintenance treatment, including attendance at outpatient follow-up appointments is required to prevent relapse"

ElementDescription: "Will you in the future need continued treatment (outpatient care or, possibly, hospitalization) for mental problems?"
Notes: "0=The patient assures us that there will be no mental problems in his/her future, and that maintenance treatment is completely unnecessary; 1=The patient is unsure about the possibility of relapse or the need for maintenance treatment, but will participate if told to do so by his/her family or physician; 2=The patient is aware that schizophrenia is a chronic illness, like diabetes or hypertension, and that maintenance treatment, including attendance at outpatient follow-up appointments is required to prevent relapse"

ElementDescription: Have you at any time needed to take medications for mental problems (nerves or worry)?
Notes: "0 =The patient believes that medications have not been indicated, and certainly are not required in the future; 1= The patient states that medications were helpful in relieving anxieties, improving sleep, or diminishing irritability. He/she is unsure as to whether medications will be required on a regular basis in the future; 2=The patient views antipsychotic medications as having favorable therapeutic effects in alleviating delusions, hallucinations, or disorganized thoughts, and states that continued treatment will be required to prevent a recurrence of these symptoms."

ElementDescription: Do you now need to take medications for mental problems?
Notes: "0 =The patient believes that medications have not been indicated, and certainly are not required in the future; 1= The patient states that medications were helpful in relieving anxieties, improving sleep, or diminishing irritability. He/she is unsure as to whether medications will be required on a regular basis in the future; 2=The patient views antipsychotic medications as having favorable therapeutic effects in alleviating delusions, hallucinations, or disorganized thoughts, and states that continued treatment will be required to prevent a recurrence of these symptoms."

ElementDescription: Will you in the future need to take medications for mental problems?
Notes: "0 =The patient believes that medications have not been indicated, and certainly are not required in the future; 1= The patient states that medications were helpful in relieving anxieties, improving sleep, or diminishing irritability. He/she is unsure as to whether medications will be required on a regular basis in the future; 2=The patient views antipsychotic medications as having favorable therapeutic effects in alleviating delusions, hallucinations, or disorganized thoughts, and states that continued treatment will be required to prevent a recurrence of these symptoms."

ElementDescription: Will you take the medications?
Notes: "0 = The patient states that the medications are unnecessary and do no good, and that he/she will not take them; 1= The patient states that he/she probably will take medications after discharge because they help him/her to sleep or because his/her family or physician tell him/her to; 2=The patient states that he/she will take medications after discharge because he/she has a chronic psychiatric illness that the medication controls (or prevents relapse)."

ElementDescription: Do the medications do you any good?
Notes: "0 = The patient states that the medications are unnecessary and do no good, and that he/she will not take them; 1= The patient states that he/she probably will take medications after discharge because they help him/her to sleep or because his/her family or physician tell him/her to; 2=The patient states that he/she will take medications after discharge because he/she has a chronic psychiatric illness that the medication controls (or prevents relapse)."

ElementDescription: ITAQ Total Score
Notes: 20% missing data rule applied: Sum of ITAQ01-ITAQ11

ElementDescription: Phase
Notes: 9 =follow up

ElementDescription: Days since baseline
Site
Notes: Study Site

ElementDescription: An imbalance of certain substances in my brain is the cause of my problem
Notes: 1 = Very Strongly Disagree;2 = Strongly Disagree;3 = Disagree;4 = Agree;5 = Strongly Agree;6 = Very Strongly Agree; 9=Unknown; 999=Skipped

ElementDescription: Pessimistic attitudes about many things are a cause of my problems
Notes: 1 = Very Strongly Disagree;2 = Strongly Disagree;3 = Disagree;4 = Agree;5 = Strongly Agree;6 = Very Strongly Agree; 9=Unknown; 999=Skipped

ElementDescription: Stressful or painful things that have happened are a cause of my problems.
Notes: 1 = Very Strongly Disagree;2 = Strongly Disagree;3 = Disagree;4 = Agree;5 = Strongly Agree;6 = Very Strongly Agree; 9=Unknown; 999=Skipped

ElementDescription: The cause of my problems comes from "out of the blue"
Notes: 1 = Very Strongly Disagree;2 = Strongly Disagree;3 = Disagree;4 = Agree;5 = Strongly Agree;6 = Very Strongly Agree; 9=Unknown; 999=Skipped

ElementDescription: An illness which affects me emotionally instead of physically is a caue of my problems
Notes: 1 = Very Strongly Disagree;2 = Strongly Disagree;3 = Disagree;4 = Agree;5 = Strongly Agree;6 = Very Strongly Agree; 9=Unknown; 999=Skipped

ElementDescription: Do you have a preference for which treatment you receive in this study?
Notes: 1 = Medication only;2 = Combined medication and psychotherapy;3 = No preference ; 999=Skipped

ElementDescription: Treatment: Strength of preference
Notes: 1 = No preference;2 = Mild;3 = Moderate;4 = Very strong  ;9= Unknown; 999=Skipped

ElementDescription: Week in level/study
Notes: 99=week 10-week 14

ElementDescription: Talking to clients about their drinking/drug use makes me feel like a responsible provider
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Mildly disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Mildly agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: It takes too much time to deal with clients'' alcohol/drug use behaviour
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Mildly disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Mildly agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: There are no/few adequate places to refer clients for alcohol/drug use behaviour
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Mildly disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Mildly agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: Advising a client about his/her drinking/drug use behaviour may lead to early, successful intervention
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Mildly disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Mildly agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: There are too many legal issues and documentation regarding alcohol/drug use to get involved
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Mildly disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Mildly agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: There are no/few role models on how to assess alcohol/drug use among my fellow providers
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Mildly disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Mildly agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: Clients will be angry if I ask questions about their alcohol and drug use
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Mildly disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Mildly agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: Clients with alcohol/drug problems usually cause problems in our treatment setting
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Mildly disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Mildly agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: People can stop abusing alcohol/drugs if they really want to
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Mildly disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Mildly agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: Treatment for alcohol/drug disorders does not work
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Mildly disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Mildly agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: In the past, referrals have not helped many clients who struggle with alcohol/drug problems
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Mildly disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Mildly agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: My involvement with a client can make a difference regarding their alcohol/drug use
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Mildly disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Mildly agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: I am confident in my ability to ask clients about their alcohol/drug use
Notes: 0 = No Confidence; 1 = Low Confidence; 2 = Medium Confidence; 3 = High Confidence

ElementDescription: I am confident in my ability to ask clients about quantity and frequency of their alcohol/drug use
Notes: 0 = No Confidence; 1 = Low Confidence; 2 = Medium Confidence; 3 = High Confidence

ElementDescription: I am confident in my ability to screen clients for alcohol problems using the AUDIT tool
Notes: 0 = No Confidence; 1 = Low Confidence; 2 = Medium Confidence; 3 = High Confidence

ElementDescription: I am confident in my ability to screen clients for illicit drug problems using the DUDIT tool
Notes: 0 = No Confidence; 1 = Low Confidence; 2 = Medium Confidence; 3 = High Confidence

ElementDescription: I am confident in my ability to assess clients'' readiness to change their alcohol/drug use behaviour
Notes: 0 = No Confidence; 1 = Low Confidence; 2 = Medium Confidence; 3 = High Confidence

ElementDescription: I am confident in my ability to discuss and advise clients to change their alcohol/drug use behaviour
Notes: 0 = No Confidence; 1 = Low Confidence; 2 = Medium Confidence; 3 = High Confidence

ElementDescription: I am confident in my ability to refer clients with alcohol/drug problems for further assessment or intervention
Notes: 0 = No Confidence; 1 = Low Confidence; 2 = Medium Confidence; 3 = High Confidence

ElementDescription: I am confident in my ability to document my assessment, intervention, and referral
Notes: 0 = No Confidence; 1 = Low Confidence; 2 = Medium Confidence; 3 = High Confidence
